title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

opener.dateline: Mamaroneck near New York 12th of the 8th month, 1794

body.p: Although I am personally unacquainted with thee, yet not so with thy worthy husband, with whom I contracted some acquaintance during the time of our yearly meeting in New York, and which was soon after increased by my accompanying him to a few meetings in our neighborhood. Since which, having been as far as Rhode Island, I there fell in with him again at a quarterly meeting on that island and was several days in his company, when our little acquaintance was again pleasingly to me revived. And having been at diverse places in in New England, as well as in the compass of our own yearly meeting, where he has visited the meetings and in some instances the families of Friends, and I find his labors have been not only very acceptable, to the visited, but, I have to believe, will to some prove lastingly profitable. It affords me such satisfaction to find that his way has been made so easy to him and such place with his friends, and that his singularities (if I may so term them) are put so out of sight in the minds of friends, that I thought I should hardly be to my own sensations, or do justice to thee, without giving thee some little information thereof. And as I believe he has come out in the right time, I hope thee will be favored cheerfully to give him up, to do that which his master his master has called him to, and patiently wait for the right time for his return, bearing in mind that those who tarried by the stuff were to part alike to those that went to the battle.
